Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved

How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: make more background readings available, other resources.

This is an excellent class and definitely the best class I have taken at Yale, and possibly the best class I've ever taken in university/grad school. I learned so much and everything was so applicable to what I want to study.

Interesting, relevant content. The course would be vastly improved by a weekly section lead by a TA. It would help students to solidify the concepts from class, review the homework, and clarify anything we didn't understand before stepping up a level the next week. 

It often felt like "the blind leading the blind" when doing the homework as a group and then deciphering our grade afterwards. TA office hours were packed and often didn't answer our base level questions, so we stopped going.
phenomenal class! I just wish that there was more grading structure so we could know where we stand.

Dr. Kaplan is one of the best teachers I have ever had the opportunity to learn from. He is absolutely dedicated to his students, the material, and ensuring we all learn the material thoroughly. He was able to relate concepts from class to both health policy as well as everyday occurrences.
He is an engaging, enthusiastic professor. I appreciate that he starts with the most simple model for a problem and gradually adds to the model.
amazing instructor. Such a good teacher, and funny too!
Very down to earth and has a great sense of humor.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student (and have!).

Apply modeling techniques (math, stats) to public health policy problems
Challenging. Make sure that you work well in groups (you'll do homework with your group every week) and you're confident in your statistics/calculus/Excel skills.
very hard if math isn't your strongest subject, but an amazing class that will teach you a lot.

I would definitely recommend this course to other public health students who are interested in learning different ways of conceptualizing public health policy problems and applying quantitative methods
